North Korean officials visit salon over Kim Jong-un 'bad hair' advert

The poster has become a tourist attraction, the salon claimed
Continue reading the main story

Related Stories

  • Leader's haircut for N Korea students

North Korean officials paid a visit to a London hair salon to question why it had used their leader Kim Jong-un's picture in a poster offering haircuts.

The poster in M&M Hair Academy in South Ealing featured the words "Bad Hair Day?" below the leader's picture.

Barber Karim Nabbach said embassy officials were shown the door and the salon's manager spoke to the police.

The Met Police said: "We have spoken to all parties involved and no offence has been disclosed."

The salon put up the poster on 9 April and the next day two men claiming to be officials from the North Korean embassy visited the salon and demanded to meet the manager, Mo Nabbach.

Karim Nabbach said: "We put up posters for an offer for men's hair cuts through the month of April. Obviously in the current news there has been this story that North Korean men are only allowed one haircut.

"We didn't realise but the North Korean embassy is a 10-minute walk from the salon. The next day we had North Korean officials pop into the salon asking to speak to the manager.

"He said 'listen this isn't North Korea, this is England, we live in a democracy so I'm afraid you're going to have to get out of my salon'."

The manager later informed the police about the visit by the North Koreans and he was told the embassy had also contacted officers.

Karim Nabbach said the advert was "cheeky"

"We haven't had any trouble since then, if anything the poster has become a tourist attraction," Karim Nabbach said.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4's PM programme, he added: "A lot of our loyal clients found it hilarious and people on the street came in and complimented us on it and it drew in a little bit of business.

"No-one asked for the 'Un'.

"It was never intended to be a political statement, it's all tongue-in-cheek. We were just using it as a cheeky ad campaign."

Last month it was reported by Radio Free Asia that male university students in North Korea were now required to get the same haircut as their leader.

  24.

    Following the Met's statement that "credible evidence of criminality" had not been found in files from Tower Hamlets Council, a BBC statement said: "We continue to stand by the programme's [Panorama's] findings which uncovered serious concerns about the use of public money, which are still being investigated by the government.

    "Our programme did not say there was evidence of criminality. The allegations relate to potentially unlawful expenditure, not to a criminal matter."

    'Youngest mother' 12:40:

    The Office for National Statistics' data shows that in 2012 253 girls under 14 conceived in England and Wales, down from 307 the year before. In 2012, 72% of conceptions under 14 led to abortions and the rate of conception in this age group is 0.8% per 1,000.

    Food banks 12:19:

    A food bank charity says it has handed out 913,000 food parcels in the last year, up from 347,000 the year before.

    Brian Milligan spoke to Andy, a 47 year-old unemployed electrician, at a Hackney food bank.

    He said: "If I didn't come here, there wouldn't be any food for me tonight. It's the system. But I don't understand why there's a gap."

    reported earlier from London Wetland Centre in Barnes on the new European blacklist of "invasive alien species" being voted on.

    John Arben explains Japanese knotweed has been found on site this year. He said it spreads like "wildfire" and "out-competes all native species".

     
  55.  
    Father defends 'youngest mum' 10:43:

    The father of the 12-year-old mother described finding out about his daughter's pregnancy. He said: "I cried. You break down with emotion. She was eight months gone. I broke down. What can you say?"

    "Sorry was one of the words said," he told LBC.

     
  56.  
    Father defends 'youngest mum' 10:36:

    The father of the 12-year-old girl dubbed "Britain's youngest mother" has defended his daughter.

    He told a London radio station he only found out his daughter was pregnant a month ago. He said: "Once a mistake is made you can only support them. I work, I run my own business. We're not scroungers. I will support this baby as best I can with my money."

    Of the 13-year-old father he said: "He's a great kid. I'm proud to be a granddad."

     
  57.  
    'Youngest' mother 10:24: BBC London 94.9 Radio

    Vanessa Feltz spoke to Serena and Amber, aged 10 in Epsom, on the topic of Britain's youngest mother, from north London, who conceived aged 11.

    Asked if she would want to have a baby, Serena replies: "No, because I like to watch TV."

    Middlesex will look to take quick wickets this morning to kill off Nottinghamshire on the fourth day of their county championship match at Lord's.

    At stumps yesterday the visitors led by 71 runs with five wickets remaining in their second innings. Listen here from 11:00.

     
  60.  
    Queensway fire 09:59:

    A woman was rescued by her neighbour from his flat on Queensway at about 03:00, say London Fire Brigade. The fire left the second floor flat, which was above a shop, badly damaged and the woman was taken to hospital suffering from burns and smoke inhalation.

    Watch Manager Matt Manning said the neighbour was probably alerted by the woman's smoke alarm.

     
  61.  
    'Increase screening rates' 09:48:

    Bowel cancer screening uptake needs to improve, campaigners say, after figures showed just over half of those eligible in England come forward for the test.

    Beating Bowel Cancer urged more people to come forward, and Public Health England to make it a priority to increase screening rates. West London had the lowest at 42%.

     
  62.  
    Last night's football 09:38: Richard Main, BBC London

    Charlton scored a late consolation goal in what could be a costly 2-1 defeat to fellow relegation battlers Barnsley.

    It means the Addicks remain just one point above the bottom three, although they do still have one game in hand on most of the teams around them.

    Popular Purley restaurant owner Gio Gonzalez will be making his sixth London to Paris bike ride in June, but this year it will be in memory of the little sister he recently lost to leukaemia, reports the Croydon Advertiser.
